posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Weekend edition

>Who is /fat/ for?
For Pudgy picnickers who are working towards a better physique through meaningful hard-work, strategy, and dedication. This is not QTDDTOT, stick to questions on fat loss. Post height and weight when asking for advice.
Join our Fatty Contest: https://www.fattycontest.com/

>What do I do first?
1. Read https://physiqonomics.com/fat-loss/
2. Calculate your Body Fat Percentage: https://fitness.bizcalcs.com/Calculator.asp?Calc=Body-Fat-Navy
3. Calculate your TDEE: https://www.sailrabbit.com/bmr/
Remember to use bodyfat% and use Katch-McArdle Formula with sedentary settings or your TDEE will be too high.
4. Plan your weight loss: https://www.losertown.org/eats/cal.php
5. Track your nutrition with MyFitnessPal (better for packaged food), Cronometer (better for generic food/macros) or LoseIt (great for both).

>Now what?
Count calories, all of them.
Eat about 500-1000 less calories than your TDEE.
Buy scales, be accurate.
Learn to cook. Try to stick to lean protein and green vegetables.
Eat a lot of protein. 0.72g per lb of goal lean body mass.
Doing cardio, even just walking, will improve your health. There is no such thing as a healthy fat heart, but you can offset the risks.
Lifting weights will keep and gain muscle mass and burn fat much quicker. No lifting results in the body burning away muscle AND fat.
Drink more water.
Read the /fit/ sticky: https://liamrosen.com/fitness.html

>DON'T
Eat refined sugars, they're terrible for you regardless of calories.
Eat processed foods.
Drink your calories (alcohol, soda, starbucks).
Freak out over a weight loss stall. Plateaus can last up to three weeks.
"Reward" yourself. Cheat days cheat only yourself.

>Other resources:
Loose skin, gyno & stretch marks: https://weight-loss-side-effects.netlify.app/
Reddit wiki: https://www.reddit.com/r/loseit/wiki/faq

Previous thread: >>69897613

posts.name: Anonymous

>>69918620
If you jump into a lot of Z2 "base" training without supporting the miles with Z1 walking and Z0 mobility/stretching you will eventually get injured due to tightness in the body. The body likes to stay balanced. You need to "reset", in a sense, your body after runs, especially long runs, otherwise it gets "molded" into a tighter position it uses during running, which can get too tight if not corrected and cause injury.
It can also just limit your muscular development and speed as a runner. I myself was a victim of this. I did a lot of easy miles, built a massive aerobic base, but it did not translate into higher speeds because of this issue.

posts.com: do i have to bring my phone with me if i want my garmin (fenix 6x) watch to track where i ran? does it have GPS in built or does it require internet (bluetooth to phone)?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69919474
The Garmin Fenix 6X does have built-in GPS, so you don't necessarily need to bring your phone with you while running. The watch can track your location and record your route and other data such as pace, distance, and heart rate.

However, if you want to have access to features like live tracking, music controls, or the ability to receive notifications, you'll need to pair the watch with your smartphone via Bluetooth. In this case, you would need to have your phone with you while running.

In summary, the Fenix 6X has built-in GPS, so you don't need your phone with you to track your runs, but having your phone with you will provide additional features and connectivity options.

>Like I'm gonna hyperextend the knees
Just don't put them in a hyperextensible position retard. You need to keep your knees bent very slightly and keep your hamstrings activated by actively bracing your legs the whole time. Most people I see just have their legs loose and are hanging on by their knee tendons, legs locked straight, makes me sick. If you go in like that, legs relaxed, you mainly use your lower back during the moment, which is not really the point of the exercise. You're supposed to have a solid athletic stance the whole time. People who say this movement is "too easy to feel anything" are just resting on it by their tendons, missing the point.

Here's my guide to a 500m test on the ski/rowerg.

You grip and rip. You fuck around to find out. you get SUPER pissy with that bat. There's no strategy, you tug on them handles like it's the last thing you'll ever do, like you're a hero of telemark skiing away from a bunch of Nazis, like you're Captain Ahab chasing down moby dick.

Don't die.

Weird old workout this morning, for sure. I really fucking love 500m tests because they are out and out sprints and if you've got power you can muscle yourself to a good time with minimal technique. Of course you go faster with better technique and there's a point after about 300m where having a bit of aerobic capacity is really going to help but at the end of the day for all adult males who have a bit of fitness sub 2:00 is achievable.

Pulled 1:48.3, which I'm happy about. I was absolutely on the rivet and dropped away from a 1:48 pace around 300m but pulled it back in the last 100m.

After that I stood around breathing hard for a while before doing my heavy KB swings.

Heavy KB swings 10x8 @ 82kg EMOM. Genuinely could have quit on these today. There was a point around set 6 where everything in my posterior chain was complaining that I was a dumb cunt and I should find something better to do with my time.

posts.com:
This whole idea of "wholemeal" bread is better, "rye" bread is better for you, etc is COMPLETE BULLSHIT.

It is all just white flour, and then depending on the bread, some extra shit is sprinkled in. Rye is like 2% rye flour added, wholemeal is just some wheat bran and germ added. At the end of the day though, it is all fucking white bread with some extra stuff. You may as well just put your own "stuff" on the bread. We call it a sandwich.

The only meaningful way to differentiate bread is by how processed it is and the added ingredients used for processing like sugar, oil, vinegar etc, vs just water flour yeast salt. There is then this sourdough vs normal bread, but I think sourdough is overrated and doesn't really do all the magical things it is supposed to do.

White bread!

I am 31 and what I have realized is that I am incapable of being an adult. I’ve seen social media normies have that “adulting” joke phrase where they do all the things expected of adults but pretend like it is hard for them and say how “adulting is hard”, but I’m not talking about that, I mean like I’m literally incapable of being an adult.

After leaving the life handholding that childhood and really even college provided, I basically just got completely lost. All the basic things that adults practically unconsciously do as they develop through their 20s and 30s seem so unattainable to me. Living on their own and moving apartments/buying a home. Getting into and sustaining romantic relationships, marriage, children. Having pets and keeping them alive. Interviewing for, getting, and transitioning between different high-profile jobs. Going on vacations they plan by themselves. Actively joining social groups and stuff with people. Even something as simple as buying your own automobile to drive to conduct your life. All these completely basic life tasks seem completely and totally foreign and impossible to me. I have accomplished literally nothing and my life is basically indistinguishable from a 10 year old’s. I even see people in their 20s with youtube channels doing shit and can't comprehend it.

I don’t know if this is autism, or adhd, or some form of another actual mental illness. I’ve heard the term "failure to launch' and I guess it pretty much fits me, but the worst part is that I see no possible way to recover from depths this low. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Your lucky day for my health dump.

Personally, I'd drop the pasta and bread. Potato, rice, sweet potato and oats, fermented buckwheat bread (super simple to make) are mostly fine. Ideally you want to hover around 90-120g carbs/day - if you're not keto.

Opt for foods when you can.. nutrients in food is typically much more bioavaliable than in a pill. Pills lack phytonutrients, polyphenols and more. But a 1/2 dose high quality (eg. Thorne research) multi, 5x/week can be good insurance.

That being said, many foods (especially fruit/veg thanks to soil depletion) and void of nutrients a continue to lose nutrients when stored on a shelf at a supermarket. Both of these can be mitigated by buying from local markets.

Wild caught sardines and Mackrell are a good, inexpensive option for Omega3 and more.

If you want to truly health max you want to be eating liver and doing occasional fasts. Do IF if practical, do a 72 hour water fast quarterly and atleast 1x 36hour water fast monthly.

A good option for nutrients is to buy 'supplelent foods' which contains high levels of nutrients (wild mushrooms, wild freeze dried Berry powders, organic greens powders etc.)

Make your own fermented foods (especially sauerkraut and fermented garlic).

If you consume dairy, always add whey to it. Whey:Caesin in human milk is 60:40, in cows it's 20:80. Caesin is inflammatory, regardless of A1/A2. 1 big scoop of whey in 1L of milk will bring you to roughly 60:40. Drink unhomogenized milk, fractionated milk fat is bad for you.

Don't consume seed oils o gluten, limit grains, don't eat from plastic - BPA FREE is bullshit, they replace with BPS

IMO the only supplement worth consuming (unless you're nutrient deficient in x) is collagen, or atleast glycine. It's too hard to consume unless you're regularly making bone broth. Arguably a low dose, high quality multi as I said earlier.

Zinc is pointless if you consume 200g+ of beef daily. Especially pointless if you enjoy the occasional oyster.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>69877115
Your fat is “stubborn” because you are insulin resistant. Insulin resistance means that you body has to spike insulin higher and keep it elevated longer to do the same job when you eat. Because your insulin is elevated, and insulin tells your body to store energy (not burn it), your fat is harder to access. Fasting lowers insulin resistance, so that’s why people have more success with it.

It’s also easier to put weight back on once you have been fat because you have fat cells built ready to have energy shoved into them. Fat isn’t just stored under your skin, it has to be stored in cells. When you first get fat you get fatter more slowly because your body has to first build fat cells which are metabolically expensive. Once you lose weight you now have empty fat cells ready to hoover up excess food that you eat. Now the fat cells will eventually get broken down once they have been empty for a long time. Or you can accelerate this process by long fasts because your body will begin recycling dead or unused tissues through autophagy.

My experience with Redmond ReLyte is that having a huge mix in a tub that you scoop out of throws the ratios out of whack because it's impossible for it to be perfectly evenly mixed. The main thing that gave this away for me was the taste, I'd add it to 32oz of water and it would have an inconsistent taste from serving to serving, most often tasting SUPER salty to the point where it was hard to drink (this was unflavored ReLyte, btw). Then I gave unflavored LMNT a try and in the exact same amount of water it not only mixed in better but tasted less salty despite having more sodium per serving than ReLyte. LMNT reminded me more of when I would make my own electrolyte mix and I'd do it one serving at a time. Since then I gave up ReLyte and switched to LMNT because I don't like not knowing that I'm getting the right ratios of minerals in each serving and it just plain tastes better.

Here's how you do it, dummy:
Bench 2 days/week, about 3-4 days apart.
Keep set numbers lower, take whatever you do on your normal "one day only" routine and divide it in half, doing half each session. If you normally do 12 sets for chest, do 6 instead 2x/week.
One day, do flat bench.
The other, do incline.
Do your shoulder work ON A COMPLETELY DIFFERENT DAY. Nobody should be doing tons of shoulder sets, 4-8 should be enough, so you can put them on a different day.
Easy stuff.

Phase I

Barrel Collecting

I've kind of just accepted that if I'm going to look the way I'd like to, I'm going to have to learn how to deal with being hungry.
Unless I'm doing OMAD (I've done it accidentally a few times) I haven't been able to eat until I've felt full.
Also, kale is my fren. I fucking love that I can just sauté a boatload of it and eat as much of that as I want. Season with salt, pepper, and garlic powder and pair it with a few eggs- that meal has been the GOAT for me so far. It's just kinda pricey.

With the cat food thing, I just make myself go on a long ass walk to the store (like 6-8 miles depending on the route) with a purpose. My cat is happy, + the time I spend walking gives me time to meditate/ reflect, and it's time I'm not spending thinking about how hungry I am/ eating. Plus it frees up another 150-300 calories in my diet. I try not to abuse that, though.
My mental and physical health is better because of my cat food ventures, and my kitty is happy. Win/win.

I believe in you, anon. It took a while, and accepting that I was going to be hungry and that I had to get used to it was a big part of it. There's not really any "SUPER SECRET VOLUME EATING HACK-SNACKS" that I can just mindlessly graze on like I want to. Which is a major bummer.
But it makes meals a lot more rewarding. I've never done nofap but I would imagine the experience is comparable.
But, staying busy has been instrumental.
Like, go for a walk, man. It feels p good when you are mid-walk and it washes over you that it was really difficult to make yourself do it, but you've made a constructive choice and you're better off than if you'd just done nothing. Momentum helps, but really getting over that initial hurdle of making yourself do something is the real key.

(side tip) I straight up can't engage in DUDE LAMO if I'm going to be sedentary, I tend to get all stuck in my head and my anxiety just skyrockets. But for some reason if I get a little busted and go for a walk, my trains of thought are more linear and I don't terrorize myself by hyperfixating on my insecurities. It makes walking less boring and enables me to sort of meditate.
>>69919418
I was honestly mad surprised. Walking is GOATED because it really isn't much work at all and like I said in a previous post, it's time you aren't eating. Kale is my fren.
